titleInfo.title: Relationship between Executive Functioning and Adaptive Skills across Autism Spectrum Disorder Behaviors

name.namePart: Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.abstract: People with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) consistently have deficits in performing adaptive behaviors (Kenworthy et al., 2010; Perry et al., 2009; Pugliese et al., 2017), which are skills needed to care for oneself, have social interactions, and to function at home, in school, at work, or in the community (Harrison & Oakland, 2015), and may be linked with deficits in executive functioning. Across the United States, diagnoses of ASD continue to increase (Baio et al., 2014; Kogan et al., 2018), suggesting that more children and adolescents with ASD enter adulthood with deficits in adaptive skills (Kanne et al., 2011). Along with deficits in adaptive skills, those with ASD also display deficits in executive functioning (Lind & Williams, 2013), suggesting a possible link between executive functioning and adaptive skills in those with ASD. Executive functioning is the ability to incorporate goal-directed behavior overriding automatic processes for desired processes (Garon et al., 2008). To examine the relationship between these three constructs, the following research questions were asked: 1) What is the association between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills? 2) What is the association between ASD behaviors and executive functioning? 3) Do executive functions moderate the relationship between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills? 4) Does the cognitive triad of executive functioning (inhibition, cognitive flexibility, working memory) moderate the relationship between ASD behaviors and adaptive skills? The current study included 79 participants (M = 9.92 years; Females = 29%). The results indicated that ASD behaviors have a significant negative relationship with adaptive skills and executive functioning. The findings suggest that executive functioning moderates the association between adaptive skills and ASD behaviors. Because executive functioning is malleable and an area of intervention (Kenworthy et al., 2014; Sasser et al., 2017), these findings are important because they indicate that executive functioning is an area to intervene and improve skills.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Lyndsay Jenkins, Professor Directing Dissertation; Lindsay Dennis, University Representative; Debra Osborn, Committee Member; Jeannine Turner, Committee Member.
